replication_study.hypothesis: In the PISA-2012 student sample, the interaction between school-average mathematics ability (standardised) and students’ reported use of memorisation learning strategy (standardised) will be negative in predicting students’ mathematics self-concept (standardised).

data_plan.dataset_identifier: PISA2012.replication.RDS (processed extract of the 2012 Programme for International Student Assessment student file)
data_plan.wave_or_subset: PISA 2012 cycle – mathematics domain; all participating countries contained in the RDS file
data_plan.sample_size: ≈480,174 student records (28 variables) before cleaning; final analytic N will be smaller after list-wise deletion and dropping schools with ≤10 students
data_plan.access_details: Unrestricted; the ready-to-use .RDS file is bundled in /app/data and originates from the open OSF replication project (see !!CORRECTION!!_Seaton_…R script).

qualification.explanation: The file provides an independent wave of the same international survey used in the original study, offering a conceptually equivalent yet new sample for testing robustness of the focal moderation.
qualification.similarity_to_original: Both datasets stem from OECD’s PISA student questionnaire and achievement data (post_registration.json: “Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) 2003”). The focal constructs (SCMAT, PV1-5MATH, MEMOR, W_FSTUWT, SCHOOLID, CNT) appear under identical variable names in the 2012 extract (get_dataset_columns output).
qualification.deviation_from_original: The replication uses the 2012 cycle (replication_data folder file name and R script comments) whereas the original analysed the 2003 cycle (post_registration.json). Hence it covers a different cohort of 15-year-olds, additional/altered country set and survey instrumentation updates, satisfying independence of sample.

data_plan.notes: Values ≥998 denote missing as in PISA codebook; those and NA are filtered. Five plausible-value achievement scores require Rubin-style pooling. Weight variable W_FSTUWT is retained but not yet incorporated in MixedLM because statsmodels currently lacks replicate-weight support; this limitation is acknowledged.

planned_method.steps: 1) Load /app/data/PISA2012.replication.RDS via pyreadr. 2) Generate uniqueSchoolID (SCHOOLID|CNT) and uniqueStudentID. 3) List-wise delete records with missing/out-of-range codes for SCMAT, PV1-5MATH, MEMOR. 4) Drop schools with ≤10 valid students. 5) Z-standardise SCMAT, each PVxMATH, MEMOR. 6) Compute quadratic terms (PV_z^2). 7) Compute school-average PV_z per school and interaction term CROSS = MEMOR_z × school_PV_z. 8) For each plausible value (five models) fit two-level mixed-effects regression of SCMAT_z on predictors, with random intercepts by school. 9) Store coefficient, SE, p for CROSS in each model. 10) Pool coefficients and SE using PISA manual (Rubin) rules; combine p-values by Fisher method. 11) Save results to /app/data.
planned_method.models: Linear mixed-effects model (statsmodels MixedLM): SCMAT_z ~ PV_z + PV_z^2 + school_PV_z + MEMOR_z + CROSS, random intercepts for uniqueSchoolID.
planned_method.independent_variables: school_PV_z (school-average math ability), MEMOR_z (memorisation strategy), CROSS interaction term
planned_method.control_variables: PV_z (individual math ability) and PV_z^2 (quadratic ability term)
planned_method.tools_software: Python 3.10 with numpy, pandas, pyreadr, statsmodels, scipy

planned_estimation_and_test.estimation: Pooled regression coefficient for CROSS interaction
planned_estimation_and_test.test: Two-sided z-test from mixed model; Fisher’s combined test across plausible values

planned_method.missing_data_handling: List-wise deletion of responses coded >997 or NA; exclusion of schools with ≤10 valid students.
planned_method.multiple_testing_policy: Not applicable – single focal parameter; Fisher pooling already aggregates five correlated tests.
planned_method.inference_criteria: Effect considered replicated if pooled coefficient is negative and statistically significant at α = .05 (two-tailed).

files.replication_data/replicate_analysis.py: End-to-end Python script that loads PISA2012.replication.RDS, reproduces all data-processing steps from the original R code, fits five mixed-effects models, pools results, and writes replication_results.csv and final_summary.txt to /app/data.

codebase.notes: The original R script is kept for reference but not executed. statsmodels’ MixedLM lacks multi-level random slopes; the approximation with random intercepts by school is documented in the script comments.

analysis.instructions: Within the container, run:  python replication_data/replicate_analysis.py  .  Outputs will appear in /app/data/final_summary.txt and replication_results.csv.
analysis.comparison_metrics: Sign (negative), magnitude (~-0.157 expected), standard error, and p-value (<.05) of the pooled CROSS coefficient compared with original report (post_registration.json results section).
